title: Mark Lawrenson's criticism of Loris Karius during Liverpool v Wolves was very weird
text:
Sport Mark Lawrenson's criticism of Loris Karius during Liverpool v Wolves was very weird The ex-Liverpool defender came up with a strange term to describe the German's failure to keep out Richard Stearman's header Share This was... confusing (Photo: Getty Images) Share Get Liverpool FC updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Just when Liverpool fans thought that things couldn't get any worse, the Reds fell a goal down to Wolves after 53 seconds. 
Richard Stearman's Kop end header gave the Championship side a shock lead in the FA Cup fourth round tie at Anfield, with home fans left stunned at the poor marking which allowed the defender to score his first goal in over 1,000 days. 
However, under-fire goalkeeper Loris Karius could surely have prevented the goal had he not been rooted to his line, something which plenty of people soon spotted. Karius stays glued to his line as Stearman scores (Photo: Alex Livesey) A familiar sight (Photo: Reuters) 
And those plenty of people included the former Liverpool defender Mark Lawrenson, who was commentating for BBC Radio Five Live at the time. Except he was very weird about it. 
Describing the goal, 'Lawro' said: "Karius sort of came out, danced around his handbag and didn't do anything." You what Lawro? (Photo: Alex Livesey) 
Did he Lawro? Or was he just static to the point being a statue? 
We've checked the goal a few times and there was definitely no dancing or handbags involved. 
Weird one.
